pli-tv-kd6:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.2: At that time the monks were afflicted with autumn illness, and they could not keep down either rice porridge or other food.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.3: As a result, they became thin, haggard, and pale, with veins protruding all over their body.

pli-tv-kd6:1.1.5: why they were looking so sickly.
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.1: Then, while reflecting in private, the Buddha thought,
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.4: “What tonics might I allow the monks that are generally regarded as tonics, would serve as nourishment, but aren’t considered as substantial food?”
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.7: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup—
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.8: that are generally regarded as tonics, serve as nourishment, but are not considered as substantial food.
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.9: Why don’t I allow them these five tonics, to be received and consumed before midday?”
pli-tv-kd6:1.3.1: In the evening, when the Buddha had come out from seclusion, he gave a teaching and then told the monks what he had thought, adding:
pli-tv-kd6:1.3.11: “I allow these five tonics, to be received and consumed before midday.”
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.1: The monks then received and consumed the five tonics before midday.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.2: But even ordinary food did not agree with them, let alone greasy food.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.3: As result of both the autumn illness and the food not agreeing with them, they became even more thin, haggard, and pale.

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.1: At one time Venerable Pilindavaccha was having a hillside cleared near Rājagaha, intending to build a shelter.

pli-tv-kd6:32.2.2: “Those things I allowed you when there was a shortage of food, the crops were meager, and it was hard to get by on alms, I prohibit from today onward.

pli-tv-kd6:34.16.2: “Sir, as long as you’re staying in Bhaddiya, I would like to offer a regular meal to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.16.3: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.0: 22. The allowance for the five products of a cow, etc.
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Bhaddiya for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Aṅguttarāpa with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks. He had not informed Meṇḍaka.
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.4: he told his slaves and workers,
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.5: “Load lots of salt, oil, rice, and fresh food onto the carts, and bring along twelve-hundred and fifty cowherds and twelve-hundred and fifty dairy cows. We’ll give the Buddha fresh milk wherever we see him.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.1: Meṇḍaka caught up with the Buddha while he was traversing a wilderness area.
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.2: Meṇḍaka approached the Buddha, bowed down,
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.4: “Sir, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.5: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.6: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Meṇḍaka bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.7: The following morning Meṇḍaka had various kinds of fine food prepared and then had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.1: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to Meṇḍaka’s meal offering, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.2: Meṇḍaka told the twelve-hundred and fifty cowherds,
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.3: “Listen, bring one cow for each and every monk and give them fresh milk.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.4: Meṇḍaka then personally served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha, and he gave them fresh milk.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.5: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.6: The Buddha said, “Accept, monks, and drink.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.1: When the Buddha had finished his meal, Meṇḍaka sat down to one side,
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.3: “Sir, there are wilderness roads where there is little water and little food, where it’s not easy to travel without provisions.
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.4: It would be good, Sir, if you would allow provisions.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.5: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened Meṇḍaka with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.3: milk, curd, buttermilk, butter, and ghee.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.4: There are wilderness roads where there’s little water and little food, where it’s not easy to travel without provisions.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.5: I allow you to look for provisions: whatever you need of rice, mung beans, black gram, salt, sugar, oil, and ghee.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.6: There are people who have faith and confidence. They may deposit money with an attendant, saying,
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.7: “With this, please get something allowable for the venerable.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.8: I allow you to consent to anything allowable from that fund.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.9: But I say that under no circumstances should you look for or consent to gold, silver, or money.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.0: 23. The account of Keṇiya the dreadlocked ascetic
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.1: Wandering on, the Buddha eventually arrived at Āpaṇa.
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.3: “The ascetic Gotama, the Sakyan, who’s gone forth from the Sakyan clan, has arrived at Āpaṇa.” And he heard about the Buddha’s qualities just as Meṇḍaka had.
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.6: “What should I take to the ascetic Gotama?”
pli-tv-kd6:35.2.2: “There are those ancient sages of the brahmins, the creators and teachers of the Vedas,
pli-tv-kd6:35.2.3: that is, Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu. The brahmins at present still sing and proclaim the ancient verses that they sang, proclaimed, and collected. Now those ancient sages abstained from eating at night and at the wrong time, yet they consented to certain drinks.
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.1: The ascetic Gotama also abstains from eating at night and at the wrong time. It would be appropriate for him to consent to the same drinks.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.2: He then had a large quantity of drinks prepared. Lifting them with carrying poles, he went to the Buddha. He exchanged pleasantries with the Buddha
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.6: “Please give them to the monks, Keṇiya.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.8: but being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept them.
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.9: The Buddha said, “Accept, monks, and drink.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.4.1: Keṇiya then personally served that large quantity of drinks to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Keṇiya sat down to one side.
pli-tv-kd6:35.4.2: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching,
pli-tv-kd6:35.4.4: “Good Gotama, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.1: “The Sangha is large, Keṇiya. There are twelve hundred and fifty monks. And you have faith in the brahmins.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.2: Keṇiya acknowledged what the Buddha had said,
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.3: but repeated his invitation a second time.
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.5: and Keṇiya repeated his invitation a third time.
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.7: The Buddha then consented by remaining silent.
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.8: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.3: mango drinks, rose-apple drinks, drinks from bananas with seeds, drinks from seedless bananas, licorice drinks, grape drinks, drinks made from lotus tubers, and falsa fruit drinks.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.4: I allow juice from all fruits, except grain.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.5: I allow juice from all leaves, except the leaves of potherb.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.6: I allow juice from all flowers, except licorice flowers.
pli-tv-kd6:35.7.1: The following morning Keṇiya had various kinds of fine food prepared in his own hermitage and then had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.
pli-tv-kd6:35.7.2: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to Keṇiya’s hermitage, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:35.7.3: Keṇiya then served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Keṇiya sat down to one side,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.1: and the Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.4: A king is the best of humans,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.5: The ocean the chief of rivers.
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.6: The moon is the best in the night sky,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.7: The sun the best of all that shines.
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.8: But for those making offerings, desiring merit,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.9: The Sangha is indeed the best.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.10: And the Buddha got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.0: 24. The account of Roja the Mallian
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Āpaṇa for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Kusinārā with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.2: When the Mallians of Kusinārā heard that the Buddha was coming,
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.3: they made an agreement that whoever did not go out to meet the Buddha would be fined five hundred coins.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.4: At that time Venerable Ānanda had a friend called Roja the Mallian.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.5: As the Buddha was approaching Kusinārā,
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.1: the Mallians, including Roja, went out to meet him.
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.2: Roja then went to Ānanda and bowed,
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.4: “It’s noble of you to come out to meet the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.5: “I’m not doing this out of respect for the Buddha, the Teaching, or the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.7: because I would get fined by the Mallians if I didn’t.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.8: Ānanda was disappointed with his friend.
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.1: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.3: “Venerable Sir, Roja the Mallian is a well-known person.
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.4: It’s of great benefit when such well-known people gain confidence in this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.5: It would be good if you would inspire confidence in Roja.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.6: “That’s not difficult for the Buddha, Ānanda.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.1: The Buddha then suffused Roja with a mind of loving kindness, before getting up from his seat and entering his dwelling.
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.2: When Roja was suffused with loving kindness, he acted just like a young calf looking for its mother:
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.3: he went from dwelling to dwelling, from yard to yard, asking,
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.4: “Venerables, where’s the Buddha staying, the perfected and fully Awakened One? I wish to see him.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.5: “In that dwelling, Roja, with the closed door. Go there quietly and slowly, enter the porch, clear your throat, and knock on the door. The Buddha will then open the door for you.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.1: Roja did just that, and the Buddha opened the door for him.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.2: He entered the dwelling, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.3: The Buddha then gave him a progressive talk—
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.4: on generosity, morality, and heaven; on the danger, degradation, and defilement of worldly pleasures; and he revealed the benefits of renunciation. When the Buddha knew that his mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path. And just as a clean and stainless cloth absorbs dye properly, so too, while he was sitting right there, Roja experienced the stainless vision of the Truth: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.” He had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. He had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.5: He then said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.6: “Venerable Sir, it would be good if the venerables would accept robe-cloth, almsfood, dwellings, and medicinal supplies from me, and not from others.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.7: “Roja, those who have seen the Truth with a trainee’s knowledge and vision, as you have, think like this.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.9: But listen, Roja, the monks will have to receive both from you and others.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.1: At this time in Kusinārā there was a succession of fine meals.
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.2: Not being able to get a turn, Roja thought,
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.3: “Why don’t I inspect the dining hall and then prepare whatever is lacking?”
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.4: When he did, he saw that two things were missing:
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.5: potherbs and fresh foods made of flour.
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.6: He then went to Venerable Ānanda and told what he had been thinking,
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.11: adding, “Venerable Ānanda, if I were to prepare potherbs and fresh food made of flour, would the Buddha accept it?”
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.12: “Well, Roja, let me ask the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.1: Venerable Ānanda told the Buddha, who said,
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.3: Ānanda passed the message on to Roja.
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.4: The following morning Roja prepared much potherb and fresh food made with flour and brought it to the Buddha, saying,
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.5: “Venerable Sir, please accept the potherb and the fresh food made with flour.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.6: “Well then, Roja, give it to the monks.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.8: but being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept.
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.9: The Buddha said, “Accept, monks, and eat.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.1: Roja then personally served much potherb and fresh food made with flour to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Roja sat down to one side.
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.2: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.4: “I allow all potherbs and all fresh foods made of flour.”
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.0: 25. The account of the one who had gone forth when old
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Kusinārā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Ātumā with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks.
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.2: At that time at Ātumā there was a monk who was previously a barber and who had gone forth when old.
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.3: He had two boys, sweet-voiced and articulate, who were skilled barbers, their own teacher’s trade.
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.1: The monk who had gone forth when old heard that the Buddha was coming to Ātumā,
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.2: and he said to those boys,
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.3: “The Buddha is coming to Ātumā with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks.
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.4: Now go and get the barber equipment, and then go from house to house with a box and collect salt, oil, rice, and fresh food. When the Buddha has arrived, we’ll make a rice-porridge drink.”
pli-tv-kd6:37.3.2: When people saw those sweet-voiced and articulate boys, they used their services even if they did not really want to. And they gave much in return.
pli-tv-kd6:37.3.3: Soon the boys had collected a large amount of salt, oil, rice, and fresh food.
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.1: When the Buddha eventually arrived at Ātumā,
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.2: he stayed in a dwelling made of husk.
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.3: The following morning that monk who had gone forth when old had much rice porridge prepared and brought it to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.4: saying, “Venerable Sir, please accept the rice porridge.”
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.5: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not. They know the right time to ask and when not to ask. Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, otherwise not, for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial. Buddhas question the monks for two reasons:
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.6: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.7: The Buddha then said to him,
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.8: “Where does this rice porridge come from?”
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.2: “It’s not suitable, foolish man, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.3: How can you who have gone forth encourage others in what’s unallowable?
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.5: After rebuking him, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.6: “You shouldn’t encourage others to do what’s unallowable. If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.7: And if you were previously a barber, you shouldn’t carry the barber equipment around.
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.8: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Ātumā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.3: he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.4: At that time in Sāvatthī there was much fruit.
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.6: “Which fruits has the Buddha allowed and which not?”
pli-tv-kd6:39.1.1: On one occasion seeds belonging to the Sangha had been planted on land belonging to an individual and seeds belonging to an individual on land belonging to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd6:39.1.3: “If seeds belonging to the Sangha have been planted on land belonging to an individual, that person should be given a share, and the produce may then be eaten.
pli-tv-kd6:39.1.4: If seeds belonging to an individual have been planted on land belonging to the Sangha, the Sangha should be given a share, and the produce may then be eaten.”
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.0: 26. Discussion of the four great standards
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.1: At that time the monks were anxious about all sorts of matters, thinking,
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.2: “What has the Buddha allowed and what hasn’t he allowed?”
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.4: “If I haven’t specifically prohibited something, then it’s unallowable to you if it’s similar to what’s unallowable and opposed to what’s allowable.
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.5: If I haven’t specifically prohibited something, then it’s allowable to you if it’s similar to what’s allowable and opposed to what’s unallowable.
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.6: If I haven’t specifically allowed something, then it’s unallowable to you if it’s similar to what’s unallowable and opposed to what’s allowable.
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.7: If I haven’t specifically allowed something, then it’s allowable to you if it’s similar to what’s allowable and opposed to what’s unallowable.”
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.2: “Are post-midday tonics mixed with ordinary food allowable or unallowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.3: Are seven-day tonics mixed with ordinary food allowable or unallowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.4: Are lifetime tonics mixed with ordinary food allowable or unallowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.5: Are seven-day tonics mixed with post-midday tonics allowable or unallowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.6: Are lifetime tonics mixed with post-midday tonics allowable or unallowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.7: Are lifetime tonics mixed with seven-day tonics allowable or unallowable?”
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.1: “When mixed with ordinary food, post-midday tonics are allowable before midday on the day they are received, but not after midday.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.2: When mixed with ordinary food, seven-day tonics are allowable before midday on the day they are received, but not after midday.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.3: When mixed with ordinary food, lifetime tonics are allowable before midday on the day they are received, but not after midday.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.4: When mixed with post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics are allowable after midday on the day they are received, but not beyond dawn.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.5: When mixed with post-midday tonics, lifetime tonics are allowable after midday on the day they are received, but not beyond dawn.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.6: When mixed with seven-day tonics, lifetime tonics are allowable for seven days, but not beyond.”
